answers.answer: Hello!  Did your regular OB do the u/s or a perinatologist?  Reason I ask, if you are over 35 and are at your stage of pregnancy, your Ob will usually recommend a Level II u/s or "Targeted study "which gives a more precise reading of your baby's measurments and growth.  Apparantly, there are different levels to u/s and what they detect, so when you go to your regular OB, readings are pretty general, basic, nothing high definition...Level II is more defined and able to give you a better indication of your babies overall developement. Don't worry, relax and try to enjoy...and keep us posted!

I know you are nervous, but be glad they did not say they found some any abnormalities with your baby. Sometimes they do get in positions that make it hard to measure certain things.The technician at our 20 wk ultrasound could only see two vessels on the umbilical cord and there should be three, so right away that made them afraid there might be more problems. I was sent to a university Medical Center three weeks later that had more detailed ultrasound equipment. Babies with the two vessel cord can be perfectly normal, but they were being extra cautious because of my age (51).  Having the second ultrasound did confirm the two vessel cord, but no other problems were found.We were then given an appointment with a pediatric cardiologist for an EKG for the baby because of my age and because if there was a heart problem I would have had to go to their hospital for the delivery with a pediatric cardiologist nearby. Her heart looked fine. If the baby's heart is healthy, there's a lot less chance the baby has any genetic problems.

Try not to worry, Munich.  PamelaBee & VA were right - it's fairly common/routine becuse of age.  It's not easy to not worry - I would know as I'm a charter member of the National WorryWarts Assoc - LOL!  Good luck on your upcoming u/s - I'm sure things will be fine - jen

I Remember when I used to go every 2 weeks for my DD u/s.  I had gestational diabetes so I had to be monitored every 2 weeks.I remember specifically one time when they needed to take some important organ measurements and my DD would not have it.  She just would not move around for them to see what they needed to see.  They poked her and rubbed my belly and I had to eat some Chocolate and see if that would get her to move.  The only thing she constantly did from her 14 week u/s on was to show us her (tmi) little hoohoo.  It was like she was singing "I am woman hear me roar"  lolIt is all part of it - don't worry.Lisa

Her little "hoohoo?"  Oh my gosh, I laughed until I almost pee'd my pants.  That is SO cute.  I called my daughters a little "cooter."  The things we mother's call our babies...how shall I say this, "downstairs equipment...."Thanks Lisa for the chuckle.  That IS precious.  "I am woman hear my roar."Heather

question: Hello,I am so nervous--this hasn't been the smoothest ride, but all seems OK.  Would just like to hear about your experiences...I went for the 20 week sonogram.  The doctor called me and says all looks great, but they couldn't get a clear picture of the heart and back/spin because of the position of baby so I have to go back for a "Targeted Study".  Some people said this is common, but at 20 weeks, shouldn't they have been able see all they need to see?  I am nervous, I have to go back in to two weeks for the follow-up.  Can you please share your experiences?  Thank you.
title: 20 week sonogram
